sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small (about 2-3 feet tall)

entries.name: Ashen Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell Minor Illusion|XPHB} cantrip. Additionally, starting at character level 3 you always have the {@spell Charm Person|XPHB} spell prepared, and starting at character level 5 you always have the {@spell Invisibility|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast them each once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast them in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast them using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Fiendish Fortune
entries: When you're hit by an attack roll that isn't a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB}, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to magically cause the attack to miss you, and a creature of your choice within 5 feet of you takes Force damage equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Scorpion Sting
entries: You have a tail stinger you can use to make {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes} using your Strength or Dexterity (your choice) for attack and damage rolls. On a hit, you deal {@damage 1d4} Piercing damage, and you can deal an extra {@damage 1d6} Poison damage. You can deal this extra damage a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. You regain one expended use when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
When you reach character level 10, this extra damage increases to {@dice 2d6}.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-7 feet tall)

speedEntry.name: Speed:
entries: 30 feet, {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}

entries.name: Azure Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell Guidance|XPHB} cantrip. Starting at character level 3, you always have the {@spell Augury|XPHB} spell prepared and can cast it once without a spell slot or Material components, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Glimpse Fate
entries: When you roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}, if you aren't {@status surprised|XPHB}, you can choose a number of creatures that you can see equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. The targets have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on their {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} rolls. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Winds of Magic
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can take the {@action Dash|XPHB} action and increase your {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} by 10 feet until the end of the turn. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 7-8 feet tall)

entries.name: Bog Bulk
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on any ability check you make to end the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition.
You also count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Guiding Bond
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can magically place a mark on a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself.

The mark lasts for 1 minute, and takes the form of ephemeral plants, moss, fungus, or swamp animals that only you can see. For the duration, you can add {@dice 1d4} to ability checks and attack rolls you make against the marked creature. You can use this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Perception|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Regeneration
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can expend one of your {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB}, roll the die, and regain a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the number rolled plus your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point}).
If you take Acid or Fire damage, this trait doesn't function until the end of your next turn.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5-6 feet tall)

entries.name: Cursed Claws
entries: You have claws you can use to make {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes}, which deal {@damage 1d6} Slashing damage on a hit. You can use Strength or Dexterity for attack and damage rolls with your claws.

When you hit a creature with your claws, you can curse the target until the start of your next turn. While cursed, the target emits wisps of fog and has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests}. You can curse a creature a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Grey Balance
entries: When you fail a saving throw, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to succeed instead. When you do, you have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB|D20 Tests} until the end of your next turn. You can use this trait once, and you regain the ability to do so when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Lupine Sense
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Investigation|XPHB}, {@skill Perception|XPHB}, or {@skill Survival|XPHB} skill.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5-7 feet tall)

speedEntry.name: Speed:
entries: 30 feet, {@variantrule Swim Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Eldritch Gibbering
entries: Thanks to your eldritch connection to the Hungering Ones, you speak {@language Deep Speech|XPHB}. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can gibber in that language. Each creature of your choice in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 plus your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} and Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma modifier; choose the ability when you select this species) or roll a {@dice d6} and consult the table below. The effect lasts until the start of your next turn. Once any target fails its save against this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

rows: The target has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls.
The target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} becomes 0.
The target can't take {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions}.

entries.name: Endless Hunger
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can embrace your connection to the Hungering Ones. Until the start of your next turn, you know the location of any creatures that aren't Constructs or Undead within 60 feet of yourself, and your attack rolls against those creatures can't have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5-8 feet tall)

entries.name: Deep Roots
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on ability checks and saving throws against being moved against your will or to avoid the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Elderwood Whispers
entries: You can draw on the memory of the Elderwood spirits. When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you gain proficiency with a skill, a tool, or learn one language of your choice until you next finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Grasping Branches
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can magically unleash the binding power of the dark wood. Choose a Large or smaller creature within 30 feet of yourself. The creature must make a Strength saving throw (DC 8 plus your Constitution modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}). On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition for 1 minute as branches appear and ensnare it. On a successful save, its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is halved until the end of its next turn. A {@condition Restrained|XPHB} creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. The branches vanish when the condition ends.
Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Root Sense
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you gain {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet for 10 minutes. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Towering Size
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on any ability check you make to end the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition. You also count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-6 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Devour Corpse
entries: You can eat spoiled and rotten food as if it were fresh. Additionally, if you spend 1 minute eating flesh from the corpse of a Small or larger creature that isn't a Construct, roll one of your {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB} without expending it (even if you have none remaining). You regain a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the number rolled plus your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point}). Once you regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} using this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Frozen Waste
entries: You have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Cold damage.

entries.name: Infused Drakkonite
entries: When you damage a creature, you can ignore any {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} it has, and it takes extra Necrotic damage equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-7 feet tall)

entries.name: Culling
entries: When you damage a {@variantrule Bloodied|XPHB} creature, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d12} Necrotic damage to it. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Gift of the Green
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can touch the ground and choose a creature also touching the ground within 30 feet of yourself. That creature can expend and roll one {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} Die, and it regains a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the number rolled plus your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. You regain one expended use when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Jack-O-Lantern
entries: You know the {@spell Dancing Lights|XPHB} cantrip. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for it (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Scarecrow Nature
entries: You don't require air, food, or drink.

entries.name: Watchful Rest
entries: You don't need to sleep, and magic can't put you to sleep. Moreover, you can finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} in 4 hours if you spend those hours in an inactive, motionless state, during which you retain consciousness.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-6 feet tall) or Small (about 2-4 feet tall), chosen when you select this species

speedEntry.name: Speed:
entries: 30 feet, {@variantrule Climb Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}

entries.name: Born in Filth
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws to avoid or end the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition or magical contagions.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Infected Cunning
entries: The plague you carry binds you to rats and imparts their cunning. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Deception|XPHB} or {@skill Stealth|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Plague Bearer
entries: When you hit a creature with an attack roll, you can spread your magical contagion to the target. The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw (DC 8 plus your Constitution modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}) or become afflicted with your plague for 1 minute.

While afflicted, the target has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls and ability checks and takes {@damage 1d4} Poison damage at the start of each of its turns. The target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the plague on itself on a success.
Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-6 feet tall)

entries.name: Dance of Death
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can make a DC 15 Charisma ({@item Musical Instrument|XPHB} or {@skill Performance|XPHB}) check. If you succeed, the next attack roll you make before the end of your turn has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}. If you succeed on the check by 5 or more, you can roll one of your {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB} (without expending it) and gain {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the number rolled.

entries.name: Eternal Party
entries: You don't need to sleep, and you can finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} in 4 hours if you spend those hours enjoying revelry, such as telling stories or playing music.

entries.name: Moment of Remembrance
entries: When another creature you can see within 30 feet of you fails a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to let the target add {@dice 1d4} to the total, potentially causing it to succeed. Once this trait changes a failed roll into a success, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Soul of Revelry
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Performance|XPHB} skill or with one kind of {@item Musical Instrument|XPHB}.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5-6 feet tall)

speedEntry.name: Speed:
entries: 30 feet, {@variantrule Climb Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}

entries.name: Bejeweled Carapace
entries: When you are hit with an attack roll, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to add your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} to your AC against that attack, potentially causing it to miss. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Silken Legacy
entries: You know the {@spell Thaumaturgy|XPHB} cantrip. Starting at character level 3, you always have the {@spell Find Familiar|XPHB} spell (the familiar takes the form of a jeweled insect or arachnid) prepared, and starting at character level 5, you always have the {@spell Web|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast each spell once without a spell slot or Material components. You regain the ability to cast them in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast either spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Spider Climb
entries: You can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing an ability check and while leaving your hands free.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-7 feet tall) or Small (about 3-4 feet tall), chosen when you select this species

speedEntry.name: Speed:
entries: 30 feet, {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} equal to half your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}

entries.name: Argent Gleam
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can channel a mote of the Silver Path's light with your choice of one of the following options:

items.name: Path's Grace
entries: You cast the {@spell Bless|XPHB} spell, requiring no Material components.

items.name: Zealous Charge
entries: You take the {@action Dash|XPHB} action. The first time you make an attack roll before the end of your turn, on a hit or miss, the target takes an extra {@damage 2d6} Radiant damage.
Once you use this trait's {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Silver Bulwark
entries: You can call upon the Silver Path to protect you. When you take Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to those three damage types until the start of your next turn. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Watchful Senses
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Insight|XPHB}, {@skill Perception|XPHB}, or {@skill Survival|XPHB} skill.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-7 feet tall) or Small (about 2-4 tall), chosen when you select this species

entries.name: Ball-Jointed
entries: You can move through a space as narrow as 1 foot wide as if it were {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.

entries.name: Innocent Mind
entries: You have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Psychic damage.

entries.name: Sewn Nature
entries: You don't require air, food, or drink.

entries.name: Soothing Heart
entries: You know the {@spell Guidance|XPHB} cantrip. Starting at character level 3, you always have the {@spell Sanctuary|XPHB} spell prepared, and starting at character level 5, you always have the {@spell Calm Emotions|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast each spell once without a spell slot. When you cast {@spell Calm Emotions|XPHB} in this way, it can target creatures of any type. You regain the ability to cast them using this trait when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast either spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: You've Got a Friend
entries: When a creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself fails an ability check using a skill, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to cast {@spell Guidance|XPHB} on the creature, ignoring the spell's normal range. The creature can add the spell's {@dice 1d4} to its ability check, potentially causing it to succeed, then the spell ends. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

raceFluff.name: Ashborn
entries: Ashborn are an imp-like species native to Chernabos (see page 22), typically coalescing from the sulfuric ash of the province's hellfire and brimstone volcanoes. Infused with the fiendish power of the Hells, this folk has managed to survive and even prosper in the barrens and badlands of the province through guile, boldness, and industriousness. Said to be favored by fortune itself, ashborn count on luck to twist the balance in the most dire of situations.

Their short stature ranges from slight to stout, but this makes them no less dangerous, for each ashborn has a venomous tail resembling a scorpion's, always ready to strike. They sport horns and skin tones in varying shades of red and gray that reflect their devilish origin, and they typically live 100 years.

raceFluff.name: Azureborn
entries: Azureborn ({@i A‑zher‑born}) are a harpy-like species native to Astramar (see page 16), often materializing from  the bright blue night sky filled with twinkling stars  and winds of arcane power. Bearing a connection to  the aither that courses through the air and land of the province, they are an inherently prescient folk that can divine the future by looking to the cosmos. They have built a society of magical wonder through grand vision, endless curiosity, and dedication to study.

Sprouting feathers across their entire body and wings attached to each of their arms, this diverse folk can resemble all manner of avian creatures, from raptors with earthy tones to tropical birds of vibrant and colorful plumage. They typically live 100 years, although many of the wisest among them have lived up to 400.

raceFluff.name: Bogborn
entries: Bogborn are a troll-like species native to Zulrogg (see page 49), usually rising from the still, dark waters of the swampy province. From the moment of rebirth, they have a symbiotic relationship with flora and fauna of the wild—and often treacherous—mire. Their ability to survive is further enhanced by the naturally regenerative biology often found in trolls.

Towering over most, these hearty folk can face any trial of nature, and they often utilize their athleticism in pursuits of hunting and survival. Bearing prominent noses and tusks, their tough hides are generally shades of green or blue. Bogborn typically live 100 years before moving on to the spirit world.

raceFluff.name: Curseborn
entries: Curseborn are a werewolf-like species native to Edwardia (see page 25), often emerging from the dense, cursed fog that rolls across the province. Sharing a strong connection to a malediction called the Grey, which demands balance at the threat of certain doom, they have managed to build a civilization of advancement and progress, countered by rampant strife, pollution, and hunger.

Covered head to toe with thick fur and bearing sharp teeth and claws, this lupine species evokes the hallmarks and appearance of wolves but with clearly humanoid physiology. If not brought to an early grave by the Grey, they typically live for up to 100 years, although technological advancement has led to certain individuals approaching 200 years old.

raceFluff.name: Deepborn
entries: Deepborn are a fish-like species native to Olmarsh (see page 37), typically rising up from the abyssal depths of the province's black sea—home to terrors beyond imagining known as the Hungry Ones. Immersed in a near constant eldritch presence that emerges from the deep and descends from beyond the stars, these folk manage their state of paranoia by embracing and harnessing the uncanny and cosmic.

While they are primarily piscine in their anatomy, they can possess features found in a wide variety of sea creatures, including cephalopods and crustaceans. They typically live for around 150 years, but certain members of occult orders have been known to live for 600 years.

raceFluff.name: Gnarlborn
entries: Gnarlborn ({@i NAR-ull-born}) are a tree-like species native to Ardengloom (see page 13), usually sprouting up from the soil of the twisted, dark forest. Their home is forever haunted by the souls of long-dead Fey, which inhabit the enormous, face-bearing trees known as Elderwoods. These folk commune with these beings to receive primordial wisdom.

Resembling gnarled trees with glowing faces hollowed into the bark, their individual patterns of branches, moss, and lichen can result in a wide diversity of appearances. Most gnarlborn live for over 500 years, but those with the strongest connection to the Elderwoods have been said to live to be thousands of years old.

raceFluff.name: Graveborn
entries: Graveborn are a ghoul-like species native to Syndramas (see page 46), typically rising from one of the countless graves that mark the frozen battlefields of the province. They were first created in a kingdom-wide ritual that twisted countless humans into new Undead creatures that barely resembled who they once were. Graveborn now wage war endlessly and perpetuate a culture of martial prowess, relentlessness, and grave honor. These people are infused with the necrotic and draconic essence of the powerful Drakkonite metal found throughout the province, which has given them a strange taste for spoiled flesh of any variety.

Appearing as the corpses of twisted Humanoids, graveborn have powerful snouts and jaws with elongated teeth and tongues that assist in the devouring of flesh and bone. Their physiology is sturdy, as if magically designed to be perfected for war. If not killed in war, as befalls many of their kind, they can live up to 300 years before decaying away.

raceFluff.name: Harvestborn
entries: Harvestborn are a scarecrow-like species native to Enoch (see page 28), most often crafted with great care by Methuselah, the lord of the province. Infused with the vital, green magic that surges through the immensely fertile land, they have a strong connection to the cycle of both the harvest and life, death, and rebirth. They feed much of Druskenvald with the crops they grow in a relatively peaceful society that puts a focus on community, family, and fellowship.

As a constructed species resembling any manner of scarecrow, their bodies are comprised of a mixture of wood, metal, straw, and other implements. Their glowing-eyed heads might be made from a burlap sack or a crop such as a pumpkin or turnip. Staying true to the cycle, they generally live 100 years before accepting the next step of death and becoming reborn once more.

raceFluff.name: Plagueborn
entries: Plagueborn are a rat-like species native to Bubonia (see page 19), typically coalescing in the pestilent haze that hangs over the province. They are deeply connected to the virulent and deadly plague that afflicts and shapes their society, which persists through cunning, ruthlessness, and the sheer will to live. They are the most adaptable species of Druskenvald, quickly discovering the means to survive even the harshest environments.

Appearing as large plague rats with humanoid physiology, their short fur ranges from grays and browns to various shades of green. They bear jagged teeth and claws that all carry a strain of plague to which they are immune but can prove deadly to others. Their nimble tails can vary greatly in length and thickness, often reflecting their family, clan, or guild. Plagueborn usually live no longer than 100 years.

raceFluff.name: Relicborn
entries: Relicborn are a skeleton-like species native to Kalero (see page 31), generally emerging from the numerous tombs and crypts that line the canyon walls of the province. They thrive in a culture of celebration and remembrance, which infuses the very essence of every member of the species. Dancing between the energy of a vivacious party and the serenity of peaceful reflection, this folk holds a deep appreciation for both the living and the dead.

They appear as skeletons decorated with a wide array of vibrant colors, patterns, and styles, and their bones are encased in a translucent, glowing substance that provides them with a similar mass and shape to other Humanoid species, allowing them to comfortably wear clothing and armor. Some relicborn can even grow hair from their skulls, which is often shaped into bombastic styles.
Relicborn typically live for 250 years before losing their form and collapsing into a pile of bones.

raceFluff.name: Silkborn
entries: Silkborn are a spider-like species native to Nerukhet (see page 34), typically emerging from silken cocoons amidst thick webbing that fills miles of tunnels throughout the subterranean province. They have a deep kinship and connection with the bejeweled arachnids and insects that have assisted them in building the grandest civilization in Druskenvald. This folk also channels the great gems that fill the caverns of the province with light and power, bringing them ever closer to the gods that spared their kind from an ancient calamity.

While this species has humanoid proportions, they have arachnid features—hardened carapace skin, numerous eyes, segmented limbs that grow from their backs, and mandibles that sprout from their mouths. They generally live for 250 years, but those at the higher echelons of their civilizations have been known to live nearly 800 years.

raceFluff.name: Stoneborn
entries: Stoneborn are a gargoyle-like species native to Pholsense (see page 40), usually meticulously carved by the lord of the province, Archbishop Danton Alexandre Renault. Blessed by the divine power known as the Silver Path, these people can call upon the godliness that suffuses their construction. In a domain of darkness, they have looked to the light of their god to build a civilization that attempts to uphold what is good and lawful at all costs.

Their stony skin matches the same hue and pattern as the stone they were carved from. While all of their kind have broad wings that carry their dense, heavy bodies, their biology can evoke a wide variety of creatures—including bats, fiends, dragons, birds, angels, dogs, and lizards—often combining features into a chimeric blend. They usually live for 300 years before crumbling into rubble.

raceFluff.name: Threadborn
entries: Threadborn are a doll-like species native to Picco, most often built with love by Blinski II, the master toymaker and lord of the province. In a land that is mostly fabricated and constructed to maximize the fun of all who live there, the essence of joy, thrill, and friendship are woven into a threadborn's very nature. They cherish the bonds made between loved ones and always maintain a childlike wonder and whimsy, no matter one's age.

As living dolls, these folk are constructed with a variety of materials, including cloth, wood, metal, porcelain, stuffing, yarn, and anything else a toy might be made of. With the most varied body shapes of all Druskenvald's species, each threadborn represents a unique representation of fun. They usually live for 100 years before falling apart and needing to be rebuilt.

subclass.name: Warrior of the Pestilent Haze
subclassFeatures: Warrior of the Pestilent Haze|Monk|XPHB|Pestilent Haze|CrookedMoon24|3

subclassFeature.name: Great Fool Patron
entries: {@i Laugh in the Face of Danger with Foolish Antics}

What horrors and sorrows can't be remedied by maniacal laughter? Warlocks that have made a pact with the Great Fool draw their enigmatic power from a powerful, otherworldly being of jolly revelry, whose twisted sense of humor is lost on mortal understanding. They are a mocking mirror to bring low the arrogant and mighty, though the Great Fool's ultimate designs are often nonsensical and incomprehensible.

Many Warlocks of the Great Fool adopt a signature aesthetic and performance style that best represents their folly. The Foolish Personas table offers archetypes of fools with suggestions for corresponding outfits and routines.

entries.caption: Foolish Personas
rows: {@b The Harlequin.} An elegant outfit of diamond motley with a painted mask—performs dances, gives eloquent speeches, and plays tricks
{@b The Jester.} A two-toned, checkered motley outfit with cap and bells—favors feats of acrobatics, tumbling, and juggling
{@b The Joker.} A vibrant, colorful suit with wild hair and bowler hat—favors silly jokes, slapstick comedy, and clumsy self-deprecation
{@b The Mime.} A striped, black-and-white shirt with a flat cap and red suspenders—pantomimes comical scenarios without speaking
{@b The Sad Clown.} A monochromatic, one-piece outfit with pointed hat and puffball buttons—utilizes melodramatic melancholy and song
{@b The Tramp.} A patch-covered coat, tattered scarf, scuffed shoes, and cigar—leverages sardonic wit, insults, and mocking observations

subclassFeature.name: Great Fool Spells
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Great Fool Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Great Fool Spells
rows: {@spell Disguise Self|XPHB}, {@spell Tasha's Hideous Laughter|XPHB}, {@spell Rope Trick|XPHB}, {@spell Spiritual Weapon|XPHB}, {@spell Vicious Mockery|XPHB}
{@spell Blink|XPHB}, {@spell Stinking Cloud|XPHB}
{@spell Phantasmal Killer|XPHB}, {@spell Puppet Master|CrookedMoon24}
{@spell Bigby's Hand|XPHB}, {@spell Mislead|XPHB}

subclassFeature.name: Killing Joke
entries: You see the humor in everything—especially in the end of things. When a creature you can see within 60 feet of you takes damage or fails a saving throw, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to cast {@spell Vicious Mockery|XPHB} on that creature. You can use this {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain one expended use when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Jester's Japes
entries: By calling down an aspect of the Great Fool, you can curse your foes. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you target a creature you can see within 60 feet of you and force it to succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or suffer one of the following curses (your choice).

entries.name: Flower Spurt
entries: You spray a strange liquid at the creature's eyes, giving it the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Clown Shoes
entries: The creature's feet or similar appendages grow to awkwardly exaggerated proportions. The creature's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is halved, and it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on ability checks and saving throws that rely on Dexterity.

entries.name: Honk Honk
entries: The creature emits sounds, such as honks, chimes, or squeaks, that are audible out to 100 feet with every movement, no matter how slight. The creature can't benefit from the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Jolly Arms
entries: Any weapon or {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} the creature attacks with, including natural weapons such as fangs and claws, takes on a comical appearance as if it were made of wood, stuffed cloth, or balloons. The target deals half damage with weapon attacks and Unarmed Strikes.
The curse lasts for 1 minute. The creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the curse on a success.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Mocking Banter
entries: Your witty and insulting japes become biting to the point of needling your foes' very psyche. When a creature damages you, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to force the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature takes Psychic damage equal to the triggering damage you took, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Once you use this {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Send in the Clowns
entries: You can call upon the laughing, jeering spirits of the followers of the Great Fool to strike down your foes. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you summon three ghostly fools. The fools are translucent and intangible, and they resemble clowns, jesters, or similar entertainers. Make up to three melee spell attacks against creatures within 60 feet of you. On a hit, a target takes {@damage 2d10} Psychic damage and has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn, or the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition (your choice). You can use your action on subsequent turns to repeat the attacks.

The fools remain for 1 minute or until you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition or you die. Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: The Horned King
entries: {@i Live Deliciously with Bewitching Power}

Whether motivated by desperation or cunning, warlocks that have signed their name in the book of the Horned King have chosen to live deliciously in a pact sealed in blood and a corrupted soul. Bestowed the power of witchcraft by the beast that stalks the deepest woods and darkest hearts, they perfect ancient rituals and weave maledictions toward aims only they know. With each victim of their malign spells filled with rot, hate, and agony, they become more like their patron until they effortlessly wield his kingly might.
Warlocks of the Horned King prefer particular implements in working their magic. The Witchcraft Implements table offers options for your favored reagents.

entries.caption: Witchcraft Implements
rows: Candles made from tallow mixed with blood
Dried bundles of herbs or mushrooms
Skulls or long bones carved with glyphs
Crushed berries or roots mixed into a paste
Iron cauldron marked with symbols
Curved blade for offering animal sacrifices

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Horned King Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Horned King Expanded Spells
rows: {@spell Animal Friendship|PHB}, {@spell Bane|PHB}, {@spell Spike Growth|PHB}, {@spell Suggestion|PHB}
{@spell Bestow Curse|PHB}, {@spell Fly|PHB}
{@spell Phantasmal Killer|PHB}, {@spell Polymorph|PHB}
{@spell Dominate Person|PHB}, {@spell Scrying|PHB}

subclassFeature.name: Witch Mark
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can imbue magic into a nonmagical Tiny object you're holding. Choose one warlock spell you know that has a casting time of 1 action. A creature holding the marked object can take an action to cast the spell (using your Charisma modifier, spell attack bonus, or spell save DC). The mark fades when the spell is cast from it or when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Malediction
entries: You can call upon the Horned King's malice to manipulate luck and fate. As an action, you can magically curse a creature you can see within 60 feet of you until the end of its next turn. Alternatively, when a creature within range targets you with an attack roll or a spell, you can use your reaction to curse the creature with your choice of one of the curses below. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Agony
entries: The target has disadvantage on its next attack roll or Constitution saving throw to maintain {@status concentration|PHB} (your choice).

entries.name: Hate
entries: The target has disadvantage on its next Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw (your choice).

entries.name: Rot
entries: The next time the target takes damage, it takes an extra {@damage 1d10} necrotic damage, and it can't regain hit points until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Spiteful Curse
entries: When you use Malediction, you can now cast {@spell Bestow Curse|PHB} once without a spell slot as the action or reaction for that feature, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a long rest. If the target succeeds on its saving throw against the spell, your use of this feature isn't expended.

When you cast the spell in this way, its range becomes 60 feet, and it lasts 1 minute with no {@status concentration|PHB} required. If the target succeeds on its saving throw against the spell, choose one of the Malediction curses, and the target suffers that curse instead.

subclassFeature.name: Crown of Horns
entries: As a bonus action, you can manifest the majestic might of the Horned King for 1 minute. For the duration, a visible mark appears on you—such as a crown made of horns surmounting your head, or you grow great antlers—and you gain the benefits listed below. Once you use this bonus action, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest unless you expend a warlock spell slot (no action required) to restore your use of it.

entries.name: Dark Heart
entries: Once on each of your turns when you damage a creature, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d8} necrotic damage.

entries.name: King of All
entries: You radiate an aura of power out to 20 feet from you. When you activate this feature, and at the start of each of your turns, you can choose a creature you can see in the aura. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or suffer one of the following effects of your choice until the start of your next turn:

items.name: Enticement
entries: The target is {@condition charmed|PHB} by you.

items.name: Wickedness
entries: The target has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

items.name: Terror
entries: The target is {@condition frightened|PHB} of you and must move away from you by the safest route during its turn unless there is nowhere to move.

subclassFeature.name: Gather the Coven
entries: You can now share the Horned King's power with those you deem worthy. You perform a 1-hour ritual, which can be done during a rest, forming a bond with up to six willing creatures that must remain within 10 feet of you during the ritual. You can end the bond for any number of the creatures (no action required), and the bond ends when you die. The bond grants the following benefits.

entries.name: Witchcraft
entries: Choose one of the curses from your Malediction feature. The bonded creatures can now each use that reaction option once, and they regain the ability to do so when they finish a long rest.

entries.name: Fly By Night
entries: As a bonus action, choose one of the bonded creatures. If you and the target are on the same plane of existence, you magically teleport to the nearest unoccupied space next to the creature. You can use this benefit once, and you regain the ability to do so when you finish a short or long rest. If your Crown of Horns feature is active when you use this bonus action, the use isn't expended.

entries.name: Hand of the King
entries: While your Crown of Horns feature is active, the first time a bonded creature damages another creature during its turn, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d10} necrotic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Horned King Patron
entries: {@i Live Deliciously with Bewitching Power}

Whether motivated by desperation or cunning, warlocks that have signed their name in the book of the Horned King have chosen to live deliciously in a pact sealed in blood and a corrupted soul. Bestowed the power of witchcraft by the beast that stalks the deepest woods and darkest hearts, they perfect ancient rituals and weave maledictions toward aims only they know. With each victim of their malign spells filled with rot, hate, and agony, they become more like their patron until they effortlessly wield his kingly might.
Warlocks of the Horned King prefer particular implements in working their magic. The Witchcraft Implements table offers options for your favored reagents.

entries.caption: Witchcraft Implements
rows: Candles made from tallow mixed with blood
Dried bundles of herbs or mushrooms
Skulls or long bones carved with glyphs
Crushed berries or roots mixed into a paste
Iron cauldron marked with symbols
Curved blade for offering animal sacrifices

subclassFeature.name: Horned King Spells
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Horned King Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Horned King Spells
rows: {@spell Animal Friendship|XPHB}, {@spell Bane|XPHB}, {@spell Spike Growth|XPHB}, {@spell Suggestion|XPHB}
{@spell Bestow Curse|XPHB}, {@spell Fly|XPHB}
{@spell Phantasmal Killer|XPHB}, {@spell Polymorph|XPHB}
{@spell Dominate Person|XPHB}, {@spell Scrying|XPHB}

entries: When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can imbue magic into a nonmagical Tiny object you're holding. The mark fades when the spell is cast from it or when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Hate

If the target succeeds on its saving throw against the spell, your use of this feature isn't expended.

When you cast the spell in this way, its range becomes 60 feet, and it lasts 1 minute with no {@status Concentration|XPHB} required. If the target succeeds on its saving throw against the spell, choose one of the Malediction curses, and the target suffers that curse instead.

Once you use this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} unless you expend a Pact Magic spell slot (no action required) to restore your use of it.

entries.name: Dark Heart
entries: Once on each of your turns when you damage a creature, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d8} Necrotic damage.

entries.name: King of All
entries: You radiate an aura of power in a 20-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} that originates from you. When you activate this feature, and at the start of each of your turns, you can choose a creature you can see in the aura. The target must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or suffer one of the following effects of your choice until the start of your next turn:

items.name: Enticement

items.name: Wickedness

items.name: Terror

You perform a 1-hour ritual, which can be done during a rest, forming a bond with up to six willing creatures that must remain within 10 feet of you during the ritual. You can end the bond for any number of the creatures (no action required), and the bond ends when you die. The bond grants the following benefits.
